Define Functions

(November 12, 2015)

The method or function, I like function, is a useful code block in any programming language as it combines lines of code that can be reused throughout the program. To sum it up it’s basically write once and run anywhere in the code where accessible; keywords “write once”.Although each language has functions, the syntax for writing them are different due to the keywords but similar when it comes to the layout. Let me start with Ruby and then JavaScript.


See below the code block displays a basic Ruby method. To communicate to the interpreter you use the keyword “def” and then the method name followed by the arguments, if any. In order to close the method you need to close it with the end keyword. In order to use the method you simply call the method along with any arguments if any. 


             
    # define method
    def method_name (argument)
         print argument
    end

    # call code
    method_name(“hello!”)

Now let’s take a look at JavaScript and you will immediately notice the similarities and differences. In order to tell the interpreter we are creating a function we need to use the keyword “function” followed by the method name. The naming convention for JavaScript is to use camel case. In order to pass arguments to your function you must use the parentheses. Last, to open and close the function you use brackets to show this to the interpreter. Calling the method is the same as it is in ruby. 


             
    // define method
    function methodName (argument) {
         console.log(argument);
    }

    // call code
    methodName(“hello!”)

One last thing. In JavaScript you can create and store functions into variables also see the code block below. 


             
    // define method
    var variable = function methodName (argument) {
       console.log(argument);
    }
